body: I guess the plugin has a recursive property, the auto discovery is not ready for that.
Stack overflow is the same I reported in #4779
Not a regression in RCs; it's there for longer time. I'll take it -- both exclude the class in question from introspection and limit the total depth.

![image](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/19204073/2e15d179-f281-4dea-b23d-0dd5d8d3f6c2)

Yep, it has been an issue pretty much ever since I can remember (8.2 or 9), same with ctrl+space and ctrl+click. The infinite "background scanning" is gone, but the issue is not.

Excluding as many files from the project as you can as well as increasing the default cache/heap sizes used to help, but that's obviously only hiding the underlying issue... and nowadays I can't really tell the difference between increased cache size or not. Perhaps my current main project's size is just too large for it to make a difference anymore.

Personally I've gotten somewhat used to finding the class I need in the tab bar and using ctrl+f rather than ctrl+click, it's infinitely faster. And thanks to windows' win+v clipboard history I don't have to worry about copying the method name that I want to find :sweat_smile:....

The sad fact is - if you want to work on big projects you gotta switch to PHP Storm. There have been bug reports, stack overflow threads, wiki articles (now available only on web archive due to the apache overtake) and no fix for 10 years.
It would be nice if someone could provide an example project to reproduce it. That way, we can investigate it. Thanks.

> I stared at the Reformatter code once before (https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/5374) and I think we should get this in :)

Yes, I looked through before for the try-with-resources "fix" and test.  That I was happier with because I was 100% sure what the issue was.  Here I'm not entirely clear what's happening when `try` is the first statement that causes it to fail, while certain other special cased first statements don't.

Thanks @matthiasblaesing 

>  I agree running a smaller number of tests that might reveal problems is better than not running a larger number.

Yes, and to put that in perspective, we're talking disabling 2 whole tests and a few asserts (all but String checks which were broken already in NB19), while enabling 329 tests.

Thanks for fixing this, Michael!

As part of the fix, I'd thought I'd bridge more reports, not just fatal errors, to indicate some lighter failures to the user, i.e. model not read well. But that is more than a fix. Can be divided into fix & improvement - more work. Please advise.

After repeated reverts bcs. of dubious code quality, I am not inclined to invest any work in RCs except really critical fixes.

With release team hat, I don't want to advise.  I didn't want to be left with the decision of whether or not to do the revert either!  I made that point multiple times.

With committer hat, it might be nice if this didn't fail quite as hard.  Depth limit and/or an actual message might be good?  I don't use Gradle enough to make an informed call on what would be a nicer approach to handling this, or even whether there's an urgency to do so.  The people who do should be advising.  We need more collective responsibility on release advice and priorities.

> I am not inclined to invest any work in RCs except really critical fixes.

worst case is that it lands on the master branch a bit later :)

But in all seriousness: non trivial changes should not be integrated after delivery branched, otherwise the RC phase will never end. There is always the next release. If a fix during RC causes trouble, I believe it is the right decision to revert it instead of attempting to iterate on it, I reverted once my own PR. Since we are running out of RCs we shouldn't ideally revert anything anymore :)

are you using search or search and replace?

since the search has two modes. The strict mode should be only active on replace since it has to make sure the file is valid. It will throw exceptions if it is not.

https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/73237de9420b5847640cae2bc5fff940d7d5b346/platform/api.search/src/org/netbeans/modules/search/matcher/AbstractMatcher.java#L87-L106

the hudson modules are in the `ide` cluster:
```
$ ls ide | grep hudson
hudson
hudson.git
hudson.mercurial
hudson.subversion
hudson.tasklist
hudson.ui
```
the failed php code folding test on windows can be ignored, it should be stabilized by #6665 which is already in master since I didn't expect that there would be another rc.

> For one-line messages I think it's actually good to have a bit of margin above and below the message; it makes the dialog more readable. 

Long one-liners are generally not comfortable to read. The main responsibility is in the caller to provide a formatted message which is perceived to look good on the screen. There won't be a catch-all solution to this. We can add a formula which sets panel width based on text length to mitigate this somewhat, but i would opt to not overdo this due to the above reason.

Sometimes having a dumb impl is better than a smart one since it makes it predictable for the caller. The current impl already has questionable input dependent behavior.

the root of this issue is likely that modifiable collections are shared over the document properties.

I believe the risk of CME is still there, it just moved from the `forEach` method to the copy constructor of the `HashSet`/`HashMap`? It should still fail if the concurrent modification is noticed while it is iterating to build the copy. (CMEs are not guaranteed to be thrown in many cases, its more a best-effort manner for bug detection, it often simply compares col sizes)

edit: i haven't checked the access pattern yet, I don't know from where else the collections are accessed, one red flag is that the empty collection is added to the properties and modified _afterwards_, i suppose someone could listen on property changes and react while the method is still running.

edit2: usages of the keys are:
 - https://github.com/search?q=repo%3Aapache%2Fnetbeans+DOCUMENT_METHODS_KEY&type=code
 - https://github.com/search?q=repo%3Aapache%2Fnetbeans+DOCUMENT_ANNOTATION_LINES_KEY&type=code
 - https://github.com/search?q=repo%3Aapache%2Fnetbeans+DOCUMENT_ANNOTATIONS_KEY&type=code
Also present is the `hudson.php` module in the `php` cluster.
@neilcsmith-net how do I remove the pending-response tag. Or can only devs do it>

@mbien Thanks for the review! It made me look what's upper on the road and found the one and only call to this method in `ComputeTestMethodsImpl` and indeed the CME has been built in the system. Here I've just added a defensive copy, this time I hope in the right place. Probably an extra unmodifiable wrapper would have been nice, though this late in the release phase I do not wish extra exceptions popping up due to that.

:+1: 

> We should revisit this for NB21 and either make the shared collections immutable

`*.copyOf(..)` ftw!

I had the same issue recently, very lengthy processing of declaration finder and had JDK 17 on Windows.
Everything worked normally one week ago.

For the moment a quick fix was to uninstall my custom plugin **blade-php** .

So there is a possibility that it is OS related + third party plugin compatibility.
I always forget that the `copyOf` methods exist. I should use them more.
They have the added benefit of being a no-op in cases where you stack defensive copies.
I don't use the blade plugin, but I'm also on Windows

@FurmigaHumana at least there are no other discussion on going about this. I think the hard part is to define what you want to accomplish and how that might fit into extensions in the future. For example I would expect the support to hook into an OpenPGP agent, just as the SSH support hooks into the SSH agent, maybe not initially, but at least with an perspective. I would try to avoid adding new API if possible. It might be required to indicate "I want to sign" info, but at least the passphrase could be provided using a custom implemenation of `GitClientCallback` and modifying the `CommitCommand` to install a credentials provider, just as is done in the TransportCommand.

I can confirm that with NB 19 and 20-rc4, if I do as @hink084 outlines above and make sure that I also have a beans.xml file in META-INF, I no longer see the error messages. Both beans.xml files are blank.

Thanks so much to everyone on this thread for looking into this!

EDIT: I've since learned that you aren't supposed to have two beans.xml files. So, seems like the real "fix" in my case is to put the beans.xml file in META-INF rather than WEB-INF.

The root cause here is maybe similar to the https://github.com/apache/netbeans/issues/3933 ( @mbien )
But it may be different because 〈Go to Declaration〉 is a part of the mouse-right-click drop down menu, and it is also can be called with 〈Ctrl+B〉. 
Neither of these ever frozen my system.
Only 〈Ctrl + hover〉 causing the freezing.
The〈ctrl + mouse click〉is difficult to separate from 〈Ctrl + hover〉 but I'm convinced that 〈ctrl+mouse click〉 is not causing it either.

I believe that the **methods header definition in a form of a tooltip** is a cause for freezing.

And I understand that it may be not even a bug, but a slowness. 
I try do avoid the word "bug" to not being judgmental. 
I call it an "overlook". 
So I believe there is a big overlook in the system that **methods header definition tooltip** cannot be disabled in the configuration.
Thus, I team up with @terax6669 in understanding that big projects can require a different treatment and developers should have a way to configure the IDE for it. There are many ways to get to the method declaration. But it is extremely unpleasant to have a feature in the IDE that can cause freezing but cannot be disabled. It is unpleasant to move a mouse away from the code field every time when you try to press 〈Ctrl+E〉 or 〈Ctrl+X〉 or something similar that can cause the movement of the code under the steady mouse, because it can be treated as a 〈Ctrl + hover〉. 

It is an UX problem.

I use blade and Windows ( @haidubogdan  ), but I cannot uninstall it.

Please check what is actually causing the freezing.

Because 〈Go to Declaration〉 is a part of the mouse-right-click drop down menu, and it is also can be called with 〈Ctrl+B〉.
Neither of these ever frozen my system.
Only 〈Ctrl + hover〉 causing the freezing.
The〈ctrl + mouse click〉is difficult to separate from 〈Ctrl + hover〉 but I'm convinced that 〈ctrl+mouse click〉 is not causing it either.

I believe that the methods header definition in a form of a tooltip is a cause for freezing.

It may be a reason why @junichi11 could not reproduce it.

So there may be a few ways to go from this point

a) this particular bug is about 〈Go to Declaration〉 , it is different from 〈Ctrl + hover〉
in this case  
a.1) it can be fixed already at some point - then it can be closed now
a.2) it still exists but neither me no @junichi11 can reproduce it - then it needs more details

b) This bug was never about the 〈Go to Declaration〉 but was always about the 〈Ctrl + hover〉
in this case:
This ticket does not describe the problem well so some description can be take from my new ticket https://github.com/apache/netbeans/issues/6634
however, my new ticket is about the missing configuration while this ticket is about the improving performance, slowness and freezing.
So, they are not duplicates.

I disagree about calling it a UX issue. The tooltip should show immediately. I have 32 gigabytes of ram, there's no reason for it to not be cached and ready to display in a fraction of a second. Same goes for ctrl+space. IMO this is clearly related to caching code metadata and/or resolving.

Even worse you'd think that this problem would only occur once and once it's loaded to memory the IDE would be working normally, but instead if you try to execute the ctrl+click workflow on the same method a few times it will freeze again, and again... but not always. If the required data is indeed cached then it must be purged after mere seconds.

I will admit that I found ctrl+b to be more reliable, but not necessarily faster. I feel like it completes successfully more often than ctrl+click, while the latter tends to just abort multiple times.

There are issues with autocomplete and refactoring as well that would be explained by NetBeans failing to resolve some metadata, however I refrain from mentioning this too often, because I believe there's a common underlying issue. If this ever gets resolved and other features still struggle to execute properly then I will make dedicated bug _reports._
I'm working on this. Maybe, I can improve this. @terax6669 's project was so helpful. Thank you!

I suspect it has to do primarily with the project size, the system performance and possibly OS (they say, NTFS on Windows is very slow).

In my experience,〈ctrl + mouse click〉,〈Go to Declaration〉and 〈Ctrl+B〉are often unstable. I suspect PHP parser may be involved, because if I make a change, even in a file that is not large, almost always navigating becomes unstable, but after a while it's working again. Also a lot of consequent navigation (clicking back and forth, like OP described) causes similar problems.

I've come up with a quick way to initialize a large project for testing. Essentially, first clone Magento (the largest PHP open source project I'm aware of), initialize its Composer dependencies and then beef it up even more by adding additional dependencies known to be large:

```sh
git clone https://github.com/magento/magento2.git .

composer install

composer require aws/aws-php-sns-message-validator:* facebook/graph-sdk:* facebook/php-business-sdk:* google/apiclient:* nikic/php-parser:* phing/phing:* php-coord/php-coord:* phpoffice/phpspreadsheet:*
```

I came across this today using Netbeans 19.

I have a Web App that I deploy into Tomcat. I'm using the Weld DI library. I have a beans.xml file located in `src/main/webapp/WEB-INF/beans.xml`. The application builds and runs as expected. 

I get warnings in the Netbeans UI on any injected beans saying "CDI artifact is found but there is no beans.xml file.". It offers to create a beans.xml file in `src/main/resources/META-INF`. If I create this file then the warnings are gone and the application still runs as expected. I'd really prefer not to have to create a second beans.xml file. I've found it can be an empty file and Netbeans is still satisfied even if my main beans.xml file is not empty.

Reproducible on Netbeans 19 and JDK 21 and an empty local repository.

Perhaps someone could suggest manual edit(s) to the generated poms that will allow a successful build of the generated projects

I checked the logs, so apparently it was requesting some CSS and JS files, whose full urls are probably hardcoded somewhere in the source code.

Anyway, the moment you show a popup to ask me for the credentials, you have to tell me what they are for.

Something like: "Authentication needed to download file https://www.whatever.com/some/file.css", plus some context as the why you are downloading it in the first place (e.g. "analyzing source code" or whatever).

This might start with getting #3523 in a stable position for inclusion and then working with the font sizing or UI scaling covered in #6676 ??  cc/ @DevCharly thoughts on this?

Yes, this has been discussed recently in the context of the IDE and all the module system add-opens / add-exports too.

One possible approach might involve using arg files for the JPMS related things.

There's also the complication that these files are treated as a shell script on Linux / macOS, but not on Windows.  Interpreting as a script makes it easier to include the default options.
I install VisualVM (which uses the NB platform) directly from the linux repo and add two flags via the start menu shortcut without changing the platform conf file:  `-J-Xmx3g -J-Djdk.gtk.version=2.2`
@junichi11 Made a rebase to the `php-nb21-features` branch.

ok, I understood it correctly after all. So the problem with branches in the main repo is that CI will think it is a main branch and run all tests (and that is a lot of tests) every time the branch updates. This comes additionally to the tests which run in the PR.

you can check it here: https://github.com/apache/netbeans/actions?query=branch%3Aphp-nb21-features

the second problem is that it will add about 800mb per branch to the cache: https://github.com/apache/netbeans/actions/caches, and we have to stay below 10gb if possible.

So if we really want to use branches beyond master and delivery in the main repo, we have to make some changes how things currently work in CI.

edit: going to figure something out
edit2: #6710

@mbien 
Interesting. I didn't know that `System.setProperty("sun.java2d.uiScale", x)` takes effect at runtime. I thought it always had to be passed to the JVM in the `java` command invocation because programmatically setting it with `System.setProperty("sun.java2d.uiScale", "2"`) (for example, in the `static` block of a subclass of `ModuleInstall`) has no effect in my NetBeans-based application. Is it possible to write a custom `main` method in a NetBeans Platform-based application, or perhaps modify the existing one? If the latter, where can I find the `main` method in the NetBeans Platform-based application?

> Interesting. I didn't know that System.setProperty("sun.java2d.uiScale", x) takes effect at runtime.

it does only work if it is set _before_ any UI is initialized, the code above is just an experiment for testing purposes.

> ...programmatically setting it with System.setProperty("sun.java2d.uiScale", "2") (for example, in the static block of a subclass of ModuleInstall)

your module is likely not loaded early enough, some UI might be already initialized

> where can I find the main method in the NetBeans Platform-based application?

The [Main](https://github.com/mbien/netbeans/blob/master/platform/o.n.bootstrap/src/org/netbeans/Main.java) class can't be customized

From my POV it depends on what problem should be fixed. The problem h1-header is displayed smaller than h2/h2-header, then I think we need to fix it in a different way (that problem would only be masked by a stylesheet specifically for h1). If the problem is "the rendering of the markdown preview looks ugly", then @lkishalmi approach to provide a special stylesheet or this editorkit is the right approach.

From a bikesheedding perspective I would see three stylesheets:
- one base stylesheet for dark themes
- one base stylesheet for light themes
- one user configurable style sheet overring the corresponding base stylesheet

The base stylesheets would then need to cover the elements flexmark could render. In the example from my screenshot I would expect a white background and the headers to be black. The gray looks strange for text display and blue for headers is also uncommon from my POV.

I also think that it worth to check/fix other stylesheet change usages which are might mess up the system default StyleSheet, then re-evaluate this one.

Thanks for the hint @matthiasblaesing !

> ok, I understood it correctly after all. So the problem with branches in the main repo is that CI will think it is a main branch and run all tests (and that is a lot of tests) every time the branch updates. This comes additionally to the tests which run in the PR.

Does it mean that all test will be run regardless of labels?
Ah, I see now, when PRs are created and when PRs are merged/branches are updated.

> the second problem is that it will add about 800mb per branch to the cache: https://github.com/apache/netbeans/actions/caches, and we have to stay below 10gb if possible.

Should we remove caches of the feature branch manually at the moment?

> So if we really want to use branches beyond master and delivery in the main repo, we have to make some changes how things currently work in CI.

I would like to use the feature branch with the following cases.
- When supporting specific PHP version
- When we have huge changes during the release phase (Maybe, it's risky to merge them into the master branch. If we find a critical issue and fix it, conflicts might occur between the master and the delivery, I think.)

Hi @Chris2011, 
I am currently involved in multiple projects, so the progress will be a bit slower than expected. And yes I tried to incorporate the solution provided by matthiasblaesing and it works, but a few finishing touches are left.

> Ah, I see now, when PRs are created and when PRs are merged/branches are updated.

right. Since a merge to master for example will run all tests. Any branch of the main repo behaves like a primary branch right now - since we typically don't use extra branches (except for cnd which is work in progress), everything happens in clones until its ready.

> Should we remove caches of the feature branch manually at the moment?

no need atm. We are still good cache size wise. It would automatically remove the least used cache first if it has storage issues.

> I would like to use the feature branch with the following cases.

lets move the discussion to https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/6710 so that we don't use this PR here for off-topic discussions.

[@Eugene-Melbourne ] Just to clarify "freeze" is used in the term as  **netbeans** is no longer operable and you need to force close the application [Ctrl-Alt-Delete] ?

If this is the case then it is not just a performance issue.
I've never faced such a issue so far, but I did manage to always fully "freeze" netbeans with a custom php plugin which used to embed php code (when typing or deleting  ":" chars).

If it's a performance issue then we can look at junichi11 commits or request an improvement on the indexing process in netbeans.

@haidubogdan By "freeze" we mean UI becomes unresponsive. There's a video in #3933 showing the issue.
